conversation.content: Hey, did you manage to fix that bug in the payment system yet?
Oh yes! I finally tracked it down [overly polite] after about six hours—turns out it was this tiny typo in the API callback that was causing the entire checkout process to fail silently.
Six hours for a typo? That's, um, frustrating—you know, I've been there though, basically spent a whole day once on a missing semicolon.

The worst part is, err, I kept thinking it was, I mean, something complex with the payment gateway integration but it was literally just "paymnet" instead of "payment" in the response handler—I wanted to actually scream.
Oh man, so those kinds of bugs are, like, the absolute worst because you're looking for something big and honestly miss the obvious.
Exactly! And our linter wasn't catching it because it was inside a string literal that gets parsed by the payment processor—classic case of the simplest problems taking the longest to solve.
Did the client notice the downtime?

Thankfully no, but they were, well, [curious] asking why their analytics showed a bunch of abandoned carts—I had to kind of explain that users were trying to pay but, hmm, the system wasn't processing anything properly.
That could've been bad—uh, did you lose any, the thing is, actual sales or were they sort of recoverable?
We sent out cart recovery emails to everyone affected and offered them a discount code, so we managed to recover about seventy percent of the transactions which honestly could've been much worse.
Seventy percent recovery is actually pretty good for that kind of issue.
Yeah, though now I'm paranoid and I've written like three different automated tests just for that one function—probably overkill but I never want to deal with that particular nightmare again.
Three tests for one function? [gasp] That's—ah, I mean really thorough but I guess better safe than sorry.
Trust me, after explaining to the project manager why we lost thirty percent of potential sales to a typo, I'd rather over-test than have that conversation again in my lifetime.
[whispering] Did they—uhh, were they angry about it or, anyway, understanding since it's just that these things happen?
Surprisingly understanding actually—she said she once deleted an entire production database by accident, so my typo seemed relatively minor in comparison to that particular disaster.
She deleted a production database? How do you even recover from that?
Apparently they had backups from four hours earlier but still lost a bunch of customer data—made my little typo feel like a tiny hiccup rather than the catastrophe I'd built it up to be.
That's actually terrifying—er, makes me want to double-check, you know, all our backup systems right now.
Do it! I now run backup checks every Friday afternoon because nothing ruins a weekend faster than discovering on Monday morning that your backups haven't been working for the past two weeks.
